knowledges.speaker: Monica

synsets.definition: change location; move, travel, or proceed, also metaphorically
_examples: How fast does your new car go?
We travelled from Rome to Naples by bus
The policemen went from door to door looking for the suspect
The soldiers moved towards the city in an attempt to take it before night fell
news travelled fast

synsets.definition: follow a procedure or take a course
_examples: We should go farther in this matter
She went through a lot of trouble
go about the world in a certain manner
Messages must go through diplomatic channels

synsets.definition: move away from a place into another direction
_examples: Go away before I start to cry
The train departs at noon

synsets.definition: enter or assume a certain state or condition
_examples: He became annoyed when he heard the bad news
It must be getting more serious
her face went red with anger
She went into ecstasy
Get going!

synsets.definition: be awarded; be allotted
_examples: The first prize goes to Mary
Her money went on clothes

synsets.definition: have a particular form
_examples: the story or argument runs as follows
as the saying goes...

synsets.definition: stretch out over a distance, space, time, or scope; run or extend between two points or beyond a certain point
_examples: Service runs all the way to Cranbury
His knowledge doesn't go very far
My memory extends back to my fourth year of life
The facts extend beyond a consideration of her personal assets

synsets.definition: follow a certain course
_examples: The inauguration went well
how did your interview go?

synsets.definition: be abolished or discarded
_examples: These ugly billboards have to go!
These luxuries all had to go under the Khmer Rouge

synsets.definition: be or continue to be in a certain condition
_examples: The children went hungry that day

synsets.definition: make a certain noise or sound
_examples: She went `Mmmmm'
The gun went `bang'

synsets.definition: perform as expected when applied
_examples: The washing machine won't go unless it's plugged in
Does this old car still run well?
This old radio doesn't work anymore

synsets.definition: to be spent or finished
_examples: The money had gone after a few days
Gas is running low at the gas stations in the Midwest

synsets.definition: progress by being changed
_examples: The speech has to go through several more drafts
run through your presentation before the meeting

synsets.definition: continue to live through hardship or adversity
_examples: We went without water and food for 3 days
These superstitions survive in the backwaters of America
The race car driver lived through several very serious accidents
how long can a person last without food and water?

synsets.definition: pass, fare, or elapse; of a certain state of affairs or action
_examples: How is it going?
The day went well until I got your call

synsets.definition: pass from physical life and lose all bodily attributes and functions necessary to sustain life
_examples: She died from cancer
The children perished in the fire
The patient went peacefully
The old guy kicked the bucket at the age of 102

synsets.definition: be in the right place or situation
_examples: Where do these books belong?
Let's put health care where it belongs--under the control of the government
Where do these books go?

synsets.definition: be ranked or compare
_examples: This violinist is as good as Juilliard-trained violinists go

synsets.definition: begin or set in motion
_examples: I start at eight in the morning
Ready, set, go!

synsets.definition: have a turn; make one's move in a game
_examples: Can I go now?

synsets.definition: be contained in
_examples: How many times does 18 go into 54?

synsets.definition: be sounded, played, or expressed
_examples: How does this song go again?

synsets.definition: blend or harmonize
_examples: This flavor will blend with those in your dish
This sofa won't go with the chairs

synsets.definition: lead, extend, or afford access
_examples: This door goes to the basement
The road runs South

synsets.definition: be the right size or shape; fit correctly or as desired
_examples: This piece won't fit into the puzzle

synsets.definition: go through in search of something; search through someone's belongings in an unauthorized way
_examples: Who rifled through my desk drawers?

synsets.definition: be spent
_examples: All my money went for food and rent

synsets.definition: give support (to) or make a choice (of) one out of a group or number
_examples: I plumped for the losing candidates

synsets.definition: stop operating or functioning
_examples: The engine finally went
The car died on the road
The bus we travelled in broke down on the way to town
The coffee maker broke
The engine failed on the way to town
her eyesight went after the accident

knowledges.origin_sent: Well, I'm going out with a guy my friends all really like.

knowledges.speaker: Paula

synsets.definition: undergo an emotional sensation or be in a particular state of mind
_examples: She felt resentful
He felt regret

synsets.definition: come to believe on the basis of emotion, intuitions, or indefinite grounds
_examples: I feel that he doesn't like me
I find him to be obnoxious
I found the movie rather entertaining

synsets.definition: perceive by a physical sensation, e.g., coming from the skin or muscles
_examples: He felt the wind
She felt an object brushing her arm
He felt his flesh crawl
She felt the heat when she got out of the car

synsets.definition: be conscious of a physical, mental, or emotional state
_examples: My cold is gone--I feel fine today
She felt tired after the long hike
She felt sad after her loss

synsets.definition: have a feeling or perception about oneself in reaction to someone's behavior or attitude
_examples: She felt small and insignificant
You make me feel naked
I made the students feel different about themselves

synsets.definition: undergo passive experience of:"We felt the effects of inflation"
_examples: her fingers felt their way through the string quartet
she felt his contempt of her

synsets.definition: be felt or perceived in a certain way
_examples: The ground feels shaky
The sheets feel soft

synsets.definition: grope or feel in search of something
_examples: He felt for his wallet

synsets.definition: examine by touch
_examples: Feel this soft cloth!
The customer fingered the sweater

synsets.definition: examine (a body part) by palpation
_examples: The nurse palpated the patient's stomach
The runner felt her pulse

synsets.definition: find by testing or cautious exploration
_examples: He felt his way around the dark room

synsets.definition: produce a certain impression
_examples: It feels nice to be home again

synsets.definition: pass one's hands over the sexual organs of
_examples: He felt the girl in the movie theater

knowledges.origin_sent: you should always feel the thing.

knowledges.speaker: Monica

synsets.definition: have the quality of being; (copula, used with an adjective or a predicate noun)
_examples: John is rich
This is not a good answer

synsets.definition: be identical to; be someone or something
_examples: The president of the company is John Smith
This is my house

synsets.definition: occupy a certain position or area; be somewhere
_examples: Where is my umbrella?" "The toolshed is in the back
What is behind this behavior?

synsets.definition: have an existence, be extant
_examples: Is there a God?

synsets.definition: happen, occur, take place; this was during the visit to my parents' house"
_examples: I lost my wallet
There were two hundred people at his funeral
There was a lot of noise in the kitchen

synsets.definition: be identical or equivalent to
_examples: One dollar equals 1,000 rubles these days!

synsets.definition: form or compose
_examples: This money is my only income
The stone wall was the backdrop for the performance
These constitute my entire belonging
The children made up the chorus
This sum represents my entire income for a year
These few men comprise his entire army

synsets.definition: work in a specific place, with a specific subject, or in a specific function
_examples: He is a herpetologist
She is our resident philosopher

synsets.definition: represent, as of a character on stage
_examples: Derek Jacobi was Hamlet

synsets.definition: spend or use time
_examples: I may be an hour

synsets.definition: have life, be alive
_examples: Our great leader is no more
My grandfather lived until the end of war

synsets.definition: to remain unmolested, undisturbed, or uninterrupted -- used only in infinitive form
_examples: let her be

synsets.definition: be priced at
_examples: These shoes cost $100

knowledges.origin_sent: It's the other five I'm worried about.
